thread.title: Larry David returns to Saturday Night Live with uncanny Bernie Sanders parody
thread.title_full: Larry David returns to Saturday Night Live with uncanny Bernie Sanders parody

author: Ebony Bowden
title: Larry David returns to Saturday Night Live with uncanny Bernie Sanders parody
text:
Larry David giving an uncanny impression of Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders. Photo: YouTube 
Why Larry David killed George Costanza's fiancee Susan Donald Trump to host Saturday Night Live It took Seinfeld creator Larry David three decades to return to Saturday Night Live , and boy it was worth it.
The famous comedian entered the SNL hall of fame on Sunday with an uncanny impersonation of Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders, who he bears a spooky resemblance to.
Larry David as Bernie Sanders and Kate McKinnon as Hillary Clinton. Photo: YouTube 
From their New York Jewish accents to crazy hand gesticulations, you'd be forgiven for thinking Sanders and David were separated at birth.
Advertisement SNL is famed for producing great political impersonations, from Tina Fey as former Alaska governor Sarah Palin to Will Ferrell as George W. Bush.
David played Sanders for a sketch parodying the first Democratic debate ahead of the 2016 election, and shone as the eccentric Senator from Vermont.
The real Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton. Photo: YouTube 
Alec Baldwin, who was playing Senator Jim Webb, and Kate McKinnon, famed for impersonating Hillary Clinton, barely got a look in.
"We're doomed!" David proclaimed to laughs from the audience.
"We need a revolution! Millions of people are on the streets and we've got to do something and we've got to do it now!"
Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist who focuses on wealth inequality and healthcare, is known for his powerful speeches and raised a record-breaking $26 million for his campaign in three months.
The 74-year-old regularly talks about the "collapse" of the middle class and is anti-big business.
David's Bernie Sanders also had a gripe with bank pens.
"Not a fan of the banks. They trample on the middle class, they control Washington, and why do they chain all those pens to the desks?"
When asked by ABC what he thought of David impersonating him, Sanders said he'd use the Curb Your Enthusiasm  creator at the next campaign rally.
"He does better than I do," he laughed.
